title: Lou Donaldson - 1954 - Quartet Quintet Sextet (1995) FLAC
description:
Lou Donaldson - 1954 - Quartet Quintet Sextet (1995)

Since Quartet/Quintet/Sextet is Lou Donaldson's first full-length album, it's not surprising that it captures the alto saxophonist at the height of his Charlie Parker influence. Throughout the album -- on CD, the collection features all the music on the 12" LP, music from its 10" incarnation, and three alternate takes -- Donaldson plays in a straight bop vein, whether on up-tempo swingers or ballads. Most of the songs on the collection are standards, with a couple of fine originals from Donaldson and pianist Horace Silver spicing the mix; in particular, Silver's rollicking, Latin-tinged "Roccus" is a standout. While Donaldson's tone isn't quite as full as it would be within just five years, he impresses with his bold, speedy technique and fine phrasing. He doesn't play anything out of the ordinary, but he plays it very, very well, and his playing is enhanced by the three stellar bands that support him on these sessions. Among his fellow musicians on Quartet/Quintet/Sextet are Silver, bassist Gene Ramey, drummer Art Taylor, trumpeter Blue Mitchell, pianist Elmo Hope, and trumpeter Kenny Dorham. Everyone plays in a straight bop and hard bop tradition, contributing fine performances to a strong debut effort by Donaldson. (AllMusic)

Track list:
01 - Roccus (alternate take)
02 - Roccus
03 - Cheek To Cheek (alternate take)
04 - Lou's Blues (alternate take)
05 - Lou's Blues
06 - Cheek To Cheek
07 - The Things We Did Last Summer
08 - Sweet Juice
09 - Down Home
10 - The Best Things In Life Are Free
11 - If I Love Again
12 - Caracas
13 - The Stroller
14 - Moe's Bluff
15 - After You've Gone

Personnel:
Lou Donaldson - alto saxophone
Horace Silver - piano (tracks 1-7)
Elmo Hope - piano (tracks 8 & 9)
Blue Mitchell - trumpet (tracks 5-7)
Kenny Dorham - trumpet (tracks 8 & 9)
Matthew Gee - trombone (tracks 8 & 9)
Gene Ramey - bass (tracks 1-3)
Percy Heath - bass (tracks 4-9)
Art Taylor - drums (tracks 1-3)
Art Blakey - drums (tracks 4-9)

Mono.
Enjoy and share!
